episodes.overview: After an incident at temple, Larry asks friends to vouch for his character – while also trying to help name a baby and worrying about a fish.

episodes.name: The Gettysburg Address
episodes.overview: Larry tries to make better use of the time he spends in the bathroom. Susie starts a new business, and her advertising has unexpected results. Later, Larry gives acting advice to an A-list actress.

episodes.name: The Dream Scheme
episodes.overview: An acquaintance from the club asks too much of Larry. Jeff and Freddy both use Larry's tactics to get out of unwanted obligations of their own.

episodes.name: The Colostomy Bag
episodes.overview: When Richard enlists Larry's help to buy a vintage car, his careless behavior leads to an unwanted outcome. Jeff secretly schemes to give Larry power of attorney.

episodes.name: Ken/Kendra
episodes.overview: A misunderstanding with Cheryl's masseuse threatens Larry's image. Then, public perception of Larry sinks even lower when he gives the wrong person COVID.

episodes.name: No Lessons Learned
episodes.overview: Larry returns to Atlanta, where he gets involved in Richard's love life and reveals a secret about Cheryl.

title: men of a certain age
overview: Men of a Certain Age is an American comedy-drama television series, which premiered on TNT on December 7, 2009. The hour-long program stars Ray Romano, Andre Braugher and Scott Bakula as three best friends in their late forties dealing with the realities of middle age. It won a Peabody Award in 2010. On July 15, 2011, TNT cancelled the series after two seasons.

episodes.name: Pilot
episodes.overview: Joe has been living in a hotel since separating from his wife, Sonia, but he's starting to think about finding an apartment. Owen, who is one of the auto dealership's weakest salesmen, winds up with an embarrassing dealer car, one his wife simply will not accept. And Terry goes overboard trying to track down a man who nearly ran him over.

episodes.name: Let It Go
episodes.overview: "Let It Go" is the second episode of the first season of the TNT series Men of a Certain Age. It originally aired in North America on December 14, 2009.

episodes.name: Mind's Eye
episodes.overview: Joe tries to connect better with his son, Albert, by teaching him golf. But when the school golf team is ready to compete in a tournament, Albert is reluctant to get on the bus. Owen is determined to get his sales figures up while at the same time not feeling bad about himself for ripping customers off. And Terry gets into his character a little too much when a coworker asks him and an actress to pretend to be an interested homebuyer at an open house.

episodes.name: The New Guy
episodes.overview: Owen and Melissa join Joe’s ex-wife, Sonia, and her new boyfriend, Harold, for a charity function at their children’s school. Terry does his annual duty as auctioneer for the event and meets an old flame, while Joe winds up hanging out with his bookie, Manfro.

episodes.name: Powerless
episodes.overview: The construction at Owen’s house is shut down by the city when it is discovered that the contractor, who has now disappeared, never filed the proper permits. To make matters worse, the electricity is out, forcing Owen and his family to temporarily stay with his parents. Meanwhile, Joe worries that his daughter’s ex-boyfriend might be stalking her.

episodes.name: Go With the Flow
episodes.overview: Joe recounts the tale of the first date he’s gone on in 20 years. The misadventures include a black eye, a potentially embarrassing encounter with one of his employees, an unfortunate piece of advice from Terry, an anxious Little Leaguer and a poorly placed lamp.

episodes.name: Father's Fraternity
episodes.overview: Joe goes to see his retired father, who gives new meaning to the word grumpy. Owen’s wife and mother get upset when a commercial for the auto dealership implies that Owen’s co-worker, Marcus, is actually Owen Sr.’s son. And Terry becomes obsessed over finding out why he has been rejected for a youth mentoring program.

episodes.name: You Gonna Do That the Rest of Your Life?
episodes.overview: Joe’s bookie finds out Joe used to be a professional golfer and decides to use him to hustle a couple of guys.  Owen’s family becomes concerned over his increasing weight.  And Terry gets a new apartment, but the apartment manager job that comes with it is a bit much to handle.

episodes.name: How to Be an All-Star
episodes.overview: Desperate to buy a house after his son develops anxiety issues related to their family situation, Joe decides to bet $25,000 on a basketball game.  Terry is forced to face the dire condition of his acting career when he agrees to take a bit part on a B movie.  And Owen’s father decides it’s time to cut back on his work load and let Marcus take over more of the day-to-day management of the dealership.

episodes.name: Back in the Shit
episodes.overview: Feeling guilty about his rapid downward spiral, which includes treating his son poorly and having to cut back on staff at his store, Joe decides to stop gambling.  Owen finds a new sense of purpose when he goes to work for a rival auto dealership following his father’s decision to turn management over to Marcus.  And Terry’s life spins out of control when his gig on a movie results in disasters at the apartment complex.

episodes.name: If I Could, I Surely Wood
episodes.overview: Although determined to get himself back in shape on the golf course, Joe finds that getting up early to practice is having wear on his body. Unfortunately, Joe also finds out that his new house is in the same neighborhood as his former bookie. Owen takes over as manager of his father's auto dealership, but is starting to doubt his decision to hire Terry, as it doesn't seem like he's able to handle a nine-to-five job.

episodes.name: Same As the Old Boss
episodes.overview: Joe attempts to create a strict practice schedule, but it doesn't work out the way he hopes. Meanwhile, Owen tries to establish authority at the car dealership, but being manager is starting to have a strain on his life, especially his marriage, and Terry gets made fun of at work when his coworkers find an old commercial of his on the internet.

episodes.name: Cold Calls
episodes.overview: Joe inadvertently ends up dating two women at the same time. Owen forces his father to stop undermining this authority at the dealership, while Terry makes a wager with Marcus over who can sell the most cars in one day.

episodes.name: The Bad Guy
episodes.overview: Joe finalizes his divorce, and discovers a few secrets about his daughter. Meanwhile, Owen goes to a car convention with his father, who has some unexpected news, and Terry is approached about an old television commercial.

episodes.name: And Then the Bill Comes
episodes.overview: Joe feels conflicted after finding out some news about his former bookie, Manfro (guest star Jon Manfrellotti). Terry begins to embrace the benefits of having a 9-to-5 job. Owen takes a huge step towards resolving the tension between sales and service.

episodes.name: Let the Sunshine In
episodes.overview: When Terry announces he's going to get a colonoscopy for his 50th birthday, the guys all decide to get one, making a weekend out of it in Palm Springs. While there, Joe deals with his "mind" bets, Terry can't stop thinking about Erin and Owen opens up about his dad and the dealership.

episodes.name: The Great Escape
episodes.overview: Joe decides to spend time with his former bookie; Terry and Erin take a new step in their relationship; Owen receives an offer from a rival dealership.

episodes.name: The Pickup
episodes.overview: Joe does a favor for his former bookie. Terry struggles to deal with the latest development in his love life. And Owen tries to keep things on the lot from getting out of control.

episodes.name: A League of Their Owen
episodes.overview: Owen takes the reins of the dealership's softball team right before a game against their rival. Meanwhile, Terry begins having relationship issues and Joe's father visits.

episodes.name: Can't Let That Slide
episodes.overview: Joe's relationship with Manfro becomes increasingly complicated, while Owen installs surveillance cameras in the dealership to monitor the workers, and Terry has a horrible date.

episodes.name: Whatever Gets You Through the Night
episodes.overview: While Joe tries to get his life back on track, Owen and Terry make a commercial for the dealership.

episodes.name: Hold Your Finish
episodes.overview: Joe’s big day – the senior tour pre-qualifier – has finally arrived. Terry realizes a new dream and passion. And Owen discusses the future of the auto dealership with his father.

title: saturday night live
overview: A late-night live television sketch comedy and variety show created by Lorne Michaels. The show's comedy sketches, which parody contemporary culture and politics, are performed by a large and varying cast of repertory and newer cast members. Each episode is hosted by a celebrity guest, who usually delivers an opening monologue and performs in sketches with the cast, and features performances by a musical guest.

episodes.name: Strother Martin/The Specials
episodes.overview: The host for the episode is Strother Martin, and the musical guest is The Specials. The skits for this episode are as follows: Rosalyn Carter talks about sections of the 1980 census intended for illegal aliens, including questions about how they got into the US, where they would hide if the INS came to their homes, and how much they would be willing to do housework for. During his opening monologue, Strother Martin reveals that he was asked to host the show because Lorne Michaels mistook him for Tennessee Williams, and so far he's been keeping up the act. At Camp Beau Soleil, the campers are forced to learn French by the brutal camp counselor, Le Capitain, but a camper named Luke is determined to escape. Additional skits include a variety show will, the Conductor's Club, Any Town, and Food. The Specials perform "Gangsters" and "Too Much, Too Young".

The NBC rerun has three changes to it: The ""Nick The Lounge Singer In Prison"" sketch has the word ""bitch"" muted out, The ""Donahue"" sketch replaces Nora Dunn's mention of Joe Piscopo with a mention of Gallagher, and Phil Hartman's clumsy introductory narration in the ""Il Returno De Hercules"" is dubbed over with a flawless narration by Al Franken.

episodes.overview: Sketches Include:   Testifying for the Kennedys - The defense is picking members for the jury supporting Ted Kennedy.   Campaign '92 - Democratic ""unhopefuls"" try not to become the candidate that loses to Bush.   Daily Affirmation with Stuart Smalley - Stuart invites his cousin, Leon, to the show. Leon has a show which is much better than Stuart's, and Stuart is jealous, rendering an affirmation.    Kiddie Metal - Guns 'n' Roses record a punk rock kids' song album.   The Scottish Store - A small-town Scottish store owner is reunited with his estranged brother, and they fight on and off, while still kicking out people who don't ""think"" Scottish.   Phone Illiteracy - A man who wants to talk to someone has his friend do it for him. Strange? The first man is phone illiterate. It's a dangerous thing...?

episodes.name: Charles Barkley / Alicia Keys
episodes.overview:
Former basketball star Charles Barkley comes back (after a 17-year gap) to host the first new episode of 2010; Alicia Keys (who last appeared on the first episode of season 27 with host Reese Witherspoon) comes back to perform "Try Sleeping with a Broken Heart" and "Empire State of Mind."

Sketches include "The Situation Room," "Thomas Peepers Insurance," "Reel Quotes," "MacGruber" (three-part sketch), "Shana at the Ski Retreat," "Inside the NBA," "Weekend Update" with James Carville, Nicolas Cage, and Governor David Paterson, "The Haney Project," "Digital Short: Alicia Keys' Booty Call," "Scared Straight," and "Barkley's Bank."

episodes.name: Sigourney Weaver / The Ting Tings
episodes.overview:
Sigourney Weaver comes back to host SNL after a 24-year gap between appearances (her first appearance was the 12th season premiere in 1986). Indie rock band The Ting Tings perform "That's Not My Name" and "Shut Up and Let Me Go."

Sketches include "Larry King Live," "Grady Wilson's Fifty and Freaky," "Summer's Eve Lady Stars of Darts Championship 1988," "Digital Short: James Cameron's Laser Cats 5," "Disco Booty Junction," "Weekend Update" with Larry the Goose and Meryl Streep, "Avatar," "Riley," "Sigourney Weaver's Internet Addiction," and "Fire and Rice."

title: the bear
overview: Carmy, a young fine-dining chef, comes home to Chicago to run his family sandwich shop. As he fights to transform the shop and himself, he works alongside a rough-around-the-edges crew that ultimately reveal themselves as his chosen family.

episodes.name: System
episodes.overview: Carmy attempts to retrain the employees of The Original Beef of Chicagoland, but is faced with resistance; in need of back-up, he brings on a talented young chef to help.

episodes.name: Hands
episodes.overview: A surprise health inspection reveals the cracks in the restaurant's foundation. Carmy goes head-to-head with Richie.

episodes.name: Brigade
episodes.overview: Carmy attends Al-Anon. Sydney struggles to gain the respect of the staff.

episodes.name: Dogs
episodes.overview: Carmy and Richie cater a kid's birthday party. Tina and Sydney work together while Marcus makes donuts.

episodes.name: Sheridan
episodes.overview: Things go wrong in the kitchen. Sydney finds solutions.

episodes.name: Ceres
episodes.overview: Richie notices the neighborhood is changing. Sugar and Carmy clean up the office.

episodes.name: Review
episodes.overview: A bad day in the kitchen causes tensions to rise.

episodes.name: Braciole
episodes.overview: Things get out of control. Carmy is faced with a decision.

episodes.name: Beef
episodes.overview: Faced with the reality of opening a new restaurant, the crew must make a plan.

episodes.name: Pasta
episodes.overview: The crew splits up to work towards their new vision.

episodes.name: Sundae
episodes.overview: Sydney searches Chicago for culinary inspiration.

episodes.name: Honeydew
episodes.overview: Marcus challenges himself.

episodes.name: Pop
episodes.overview: The renovation gets off track.

episodes.name: Fishes
episodes.overview: Feast of the Seven Fishes.

episodes.name: Forks
episodes.overview: Richie stages.

episodes.name: Bolognese
episodes.overview: The crew awaits a do-or-die fire suppression test.

episodes.name: Omelette
episodes.overview: Final preparations are made for The Bear's first service.

episodes.name: The Bear
episodes.overview: Friends & Family night at The Bear.

episodes.name: Tomorrow
episodes.overview: The next day and the days that led to it.

episodes.name: Next
episodes.overview: Carmy sets a new standard.

episodes.name: Doors
episodes.overview: The staff slogs through a month of service.

episodes.name: Violet
episodes.overview: Sydney gets a new apartment. Marcus finds inspiration.

episodes.name: Children
episodes.overview: The Computer gives The Bear its odds.

episodes.name: Napkins
episodes.overview: Tina looks for a new opportunity.

episodes.name: Legacy
episodes.overview: The restaurant is out of C-Folds. Sydney is presented with an opportunity.

episodes.name: Ice Chips
episodes.overview: Sugar finds support in an unexpected place.

episodes.name: Apologies
episodes.overview: Carmy thinks about apologizing.

episodes.name: Forever
episodes.overview: Another funeral.

title: last week tonight
overview: A half-hour satirical look at the week in news, politics and current events.

episodes.name: POM Wonderful v. Coca-Cola
episodes.overview: John talks about the Indian election, Pom Wonderful and talks with the former NSA Director General Keith Alexander.

episodes.name: Capital Punishment
episodes.overview: John talks about the recent issues of the death penalty, François Hollande and the rising issues happening in Brunei.

episodes.name: Climate Change Denial
episodes.overview: John talks about Eurovision, Ukraine and Russia's relations and interviews Bill Nye about Climate Change.

episodes.name: The Right to Be Forgotten
episodes.overview: John talks about the product recall going on at General Motors, the EU Court of Justice "Right to be Forgotten" ruling and updates us on how the Indian election is going with help from Fareed Zakaria.

episodes.name: Net Neutrality
episodes.overview: John talks about the rise of the far-right political parties in Europe, the Ukrainian election, Afghanistan, Net Neutrality, Australia's hard-line right-wing Prime Minister Tony Abbott and the 2014 Scripps National Spelling Bee.

episodes.name: FIFA and the World Cup
episodes.overview: John talks about California Chrome and the Belmont Stakes, FIFA and the 2014 World Cup, and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

episodes.name: Immigration Reform
episodes.overview: John talks about US Immigration and interviews Professor Stephen Hawking.

episodes.name: Dr. Oz
episodes.overview: John talks about Iraq, Antarctica tourism and Dr. Oz's "Miracle Drug".

episodes.name: Burwell v. Hobby Lobby
episodes.overview: John Oliver sheds light on recent Supreme Court cases and discusses gay rights in Uganda with activist Pepe Julian Onziema.

episodes.name: Income and Wealth Inequality
episodes.overview: John talks about modern American income inequality, Warren G. Harding's love letters and President Obama's "Day In The Life" tour.

episodes.name: Incarceration in the United States
episodes.overview: John talks about the Gaza crisis, the decay of American prisons and the gambling addiction problem in Singapore.

episodes.name: Nuclear Weapons and the United States
episodes.overview: John talks about human rights violations in the Middle East, nuclear disarmament and Russia's science satellite that lost communication.

episodes.name: Native Advertising
episodes.overview: John talks about Uganda's anti-gay laws, the CIA's recent report on their use of torture, the New York Port Authority, Argentina's default on debt and native advertising.

episodes.name: Payday Loans
episodes.overview: John talks about the return of US military actions in Iraq, replacing all passwords due to a global security breach and the terrible practices of the Payday Loan industry.

episodes.name: Shooting of Michael Brown and Police Militarization
episodes.overview: Focuses on the shooting of Michael Brown and police militarization in Ferguson, MO. John also discusses the topic of equal pay for equal work.

episodes.name: Student Debt
episodes.overview: John talks about ISIS and student loan debt. Musical group A Great Big World make a special appearance.

episodes.name: Scottish Independence Referendum
episodes.overview: John talks about the NFL's decision on Ray Rice's contract, the international response to ISIS, Scotland's separation from the United Kingdom and Twitter hashtags that are being misused by corporations.

episodes.name: United States Embargo Against Cuba, Miss America 2015
episodes.overview:
John covers the results of the Scottish referendum that took place the week before and explains why the policy of United States having embargo against Cuba doesn't make sense .

The main story focuses on the Miss America pageant and their scholarships to women. John explains how outdated and absurd the requirements for the contestants are and to illustrate these problems, stages his own pageant with the help of a guest star - Kathy Griffin.

episodes.name: Drones
episodes.overview: John discusses U.S. military drones and the Kansas state budget shortfall. Also, Narendra Modi, the Prime Minster of India visited New York and did some classic New York things.

episodes.name: Civil Forfeiture
episodes.overview: Main story: how desperate the American law enforcement is to make money out of everyone by using the process called the "civil asset forfeiture," and how it would make for a weird episode of "Law and Order." Plus, John wants to host the 2022 Winter Olympics and how is Columbus Day still a thing.

episodes.name: Military Translators
episodes.overview: Translators who have aided the U.S. Military in Afghanistan and Iraq are in great danger in their home countries, but red tape is making it impossible for many of them to leave. John Oliver interviews FNU Mohammad, one translator who made it out. Plus, since cameras aren’t allowed in the Supreme Court discussions, most coverage of the important cases looks like garbage. John fixes that problem with real animals and fake paws.

episodes.name: Sugar
episodes.overview: John Oliver talks about a Russian submarine in Sweden, ebola in New York, added sugar in food, Rob Ford's brother and interviews Jane Goodall.

episodes.name: State Legislatures and ALEC
episodes.overview: While midterm coverage is largely focused on the parts of Congress that do very little, vital (and bizarre) midterm elections are going unexamined. State legislators pass a lot of bills, and some of that efficiency is thanks to a group called ALEC that writes legislation for them. It’s as shady as it sounds!

episodes.name: The Lottery
episodes.overview:
The Lottery: State lotteries claim to be good for education and the general wellbeing of citizens. But are they? (Spoiler alert: No.)

Also, there is a cannon that shoots salmon over dams. It’s awesome. Check it out.

episodes.name: Marketing to Doctors
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the growing issues of pharmaceutical companies marketing directly to and through doctors. Also, since RadioShack has filed for bankruptcy, John has created a farewell message for them. Plus, the online sessions by Ecuadorian President Rafael Correa to address the public aren't going too well.

episodes.name: Tobacco
episodes.overview: Thanks to tobacco industry regulations and marketing restrictions in the U.S., smoking rates have dropped dramatically. John Oliver explains how tobacco companies are keeping their business strong overseas and how Phillip Morris International in particular is employing some unethical legal practices while suing some of the world's poorest countries. Plus, we've noticed that the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue still exists but can’t quite figure out why.

episodes.name: Elected Judges
episodes.overview:
The vast majority of US judges are elected, forcing many judges to pander to the electorate and accept campaign money in order to keep their jobs. This seems slightly troubling... 

The UK's Labour Party has painted a campaign van pink in an attempt to attract women voters. We are glad they didn't keep going with that strategy.

episodes.name: Infrastructure
episodes.overview: America's crumbling infrastructure: It's not a sexy problem, but it is a scary one.

episodes.name: U.S. Territories
episodes.overview: A set of Supreme Court decisions made over 100 years ago has left U.S. territories without meaningful representation. That’s weird, right? Plus, daylight saving time doesn’t actually benefit anyone. Strangely, it’s still a thing!

episodes.name: The NCAA
episodes.overview: The NCAA doesn’t pay athletes because they consider them amateurs. The NCAA considers them amateurs because they don’t get paid.

episodes.name: Municipal Violations
episodes.overview: If you have money, committing a municipal violation may pose you a minor inconvenience. If you don’t, it can ruin your life. Also, the New Hampshire legislature refused to make the red-tailed hawk the official raptor of their state... so Last Week Tonight made it the official raptor of the show.

episodes.name: Government Surveillance
episodes.overview: There are very few government checks on what America’s sweeping surveillance programs are capable of doing. John Oliver sits down with Edward Snowden to discuss the NSA, the balance between privacy and security, and dick-pics.

episodes.name: The IRS
episodes.overview: Nobody likes the IRS. But recent budget and staff cuts have made it increasingly difficult for the department to do its very important job. Don’t take our word for it. Ask Michael Bolton.

episodes.name: Patents
episodes.overview: For inventors, patents are an essential protection against theft. But when patent trolls abuse the system by stockpiling patents and threatening lawsuits, businesses are forced to shell out tons of money. Also, CNN produced an actual doomsday video to broadcast when the world is ending and it’s incredibly dull. We've enlisted Martin Sheen to help make humanity’s final moments happier!

episodes.name: Fashion
episodes.overview: John explores the concept of changing and cheap fashion and some of the ugliest truths of the manufacturing process.

episodes.name: Standardized Testing
episodes.overview: American students face a ridiculous amount of testing. John Oliver explains how standardized tests impact school funding, the achievement gap and how often the kids are expected to throw up while taking one.

episodes.name: Paid Family Leave
episodes.overview: Many American companies do not offer paid leave after the birth of a child, which means they probably shouldn’t run sappy Mother’s Day ads. Also, the Japanese have some unhealthy obsession with mascots and John proposes to adopt some of that culture in the U.S. government agencies as well.

episodes.name: Chickens
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how chicken farming can be unfair, punishing, and inhumane. And not just for the chickens!

episodes.name: FIFA II
episodes.overview: After the arrests of numerous top officials, John Oliver decided to give an update on the state of FIFA. Also, Thailand's ignorance about the world's history involving Hitler might require some re-education.

episodes.name: Bail
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why America’s bail system is better for the reality TV industry than it is for the justice system.

episodes.name: Torture
episodes.overview: The US Senate Torture Report revealed horrifying details of America's interrogation program. Helen Mirren will fill you in. Plus, information about the 2015 European Games and the Canadian Senate expenses scandal.

episodes.name: The Internet
episodes.overview: Online harassment is a major problem, but it’s rarely prosecuted. If only we’d been warned about this in the early days of the internet.

episodes.name: Transgender Rights
episodes.overview: This week’s gay rights victory was historic, but the transgender community still faces staggering challenges. John Oliver focuses on the “T” in “LGBT."

episodes.name: Stadiums
episodes.overview: Cities spend massive amounts of public money on privately-owned stadiums. Cities issue tax-exempt municipal bonds that — wait, don’t fall asleep!

episodes.name: Food Waste
episodes.overview: Producers, sellers, and consumers waste tons of food. John Oliver discusses the shocking amount of food we don’t eat.

episodes.name: Mandatory Minimum Sentencing Laws
episodes.overview: Mandatory minimums require fixed prison sentences for certain crimes. John Oliver explains why we treat some turkeys better than most low-level offenders.

episodes.name: District of Columbia
episodes.overview: Washington DC experiences taxation without representation. It's also missing from rhyming state songs. John Oliver and a group of singing children fix one of these problems. Plus, a sex scandal involving the Chairman of the British House of Lords.

episodes.name: Sex Education
episodes.overview: Sex education varies widely between school districts, leaving many teens without comprehensive information. We made a video that covers what some schools are too embarrassed to teach.

episodes.name: Church
episodes.overview: John discusses predatory churches and televangelism, and how the U.S. tax law allows them to get away with almost anything. Plus, the raising of the American flag in Cuba, the redesign of New Zealand's flag, and President Harding's illegitimate child.

episodes.name: LGBT Discrimination
episodes.overview: This year’s gay marriage ruling was a milestone, but LGBT discrimination is still surprisingly legal. John Oliver explains why we need a federal anti-discrimination law. Plus, the rising tensions on the border between North and South Korea, and why Vladimir Putin has started a war on food.

episodes.name: Public Defenders
episodes.overview: The Miranda warning includes the right to a public defender. It doesn’t include the fact that public defenders are highly overworked and grossly underpaid. Plus, a Michigan state legislature scandal, Guatemala's unusual election, and the longevity of Queen Elizabeth II.

episodes.name: Migrants and Refugees
episodes.overview: Millions of migrants seeking asylum in Europe face hostility, racism, and red tape. John Oliver does one admittedly tiny thing for one of them. Plus Pope's visit to the U.S., the unsavory practices of Volkswagen car manufacturer, and some shocking allegations about the activities of former British PM David Cameron.

episodes.name: Mental Health
episodes.overview: John discusses Russia's involvement in Syria, the U.N. General Assembly, and the problems with the national system for treating mental illness. Plus, why creating a Yelp-like app for rating other people seems like a bad idea.

episodes.name: North Dakota
episodes.overview: North Dakota is known for being polite, but perhaps they’ve been a little too hospitable to oil companies. Plus, the mess atop of FIFA's leadership and the connection between Toyota and ISIS.

episodes.name: Canada
episodes.overview: Canada is about to have a major election. John Oliver enlists Mike Myers, a beaver, and a moose to give voters some advice. Plus, the unpopularity of the Mexican president Enrique Peña Nieto and the habit of American politicians to misquote historical figures.

episodes.name: Medicaid Gap
episodes.overview: John Oliver looks at the upcoming local state elections, the results of which could affect the lives of millions of Americans that are looking for Medicaid assistance. Plus, the 'peace talks' held in Vienna, Austria concerning the war in Syria gather nearly 20 countries, but not a single representative from Syria itself. And how Kenny G could help de-escalate the tension between China and its neighbors in South China Sea.

episodes.name: Prisoner Re-entry
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses problems that prisoners face when re-entering the society after they're released from prison. A quick interview with Bilal Chatman shines a light on one such case. Plus, a law proposed in the United Kingdom advocates for a mass surveillance of citizens' online activities, how Department of Defense is paying huge sums of money to professional sports teams to honor veterans during their events, and Washington Redskins file a lawsuit to defend their poorly chosen trademark name by naming other terrible examples.

episodes.name: Daily Fantasy Sports
episodes.overview: John talks about the recent Paris attacks, China's Singles Day, the Koh-i-Noor diamond and Daily Fantasy Sports.

episodes.name: Refugees & Pennies
episodes.overview: John reflects on the aftermath of Paris attacks and how it affects refugees worldwide. Plus, he questions the usefulness of the U.S. penny, since minting the coins costs more than they're actually worth.

episodes.name: Voting
episodes.overview: John talks about the late Antonin Scalia's love of the Letter of the Law, Chipotle's food safety problems, how Voter IDs laws should be applied to those who write them, and New Zealand's economic development minister Steven Joyce.

episodes.name: Abortion Laws
episodes.overview: John talks about the South Carolina Republican primary, the Supreme Court vacancy and abortion, which theoretically is legal in the U.S., but some states make it practically inaccessible. Plus, how is Hollywood whitewashing still a thing?

episodes.name: Donald Trump
episodes.overview: John talks about the Egyptian president and economic crisis, the Guantanamo Bay shutdown and Donald Trump.

episodes.name: Special Districts
episodes.overview: Special districts spend more public money than all city governments combined. That's odd considering most of us don't know they exist.

episodes.name: Encryption
episodes.overview: Strong encryption poses problems for law enforcement, is weakening it worth the risks it presents? It’s…complicated.

episodes.name: Border Wall
episodes.overview: Donald Drumpf wants to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border. Is his plan feasible?

episodes.name: Congressional Fundraising
episodes.overview: Lawmakers have to raise money to keep their jobs, but a surprising amount of their job now consists of raising money. John Oliver sits down with Congressman Steve Israel to discuss the costs of political spending.

episodes.name: Credit Reports
episodes.overview: Credit reports play a surprisingly large role in our lives, but even more surprising is how often they contain critical mistakes. John Oliver helps credit agencies see why this is a problem.

episodes.name: Lead
episodes.overview: Lead poisoning is a national problem. If only lawmakers were as concerned as the puppets on Sesame Street.

episodes.name: Puerto Rico
episodes.overview: Puerto Rico is suffering a massive debt crisis. Lin-Manuel Miranda joins John Oliver to call for relief.

episodes.name: Scientific Studies
episodes.overview: John Oliver on Sticking to the Facts: Media outlets often report new findings from scientific studies, but how many are true?

John Oliver on 911 Reliability: Things you never want to hear: there are no guarantees when you call 911. Emergency call centers are in desperate need of funding and new technology, so “no guarantees” is the unfortunate reality.

episodes.name: Primaries and Caucuses
episodes.overview: Last Week Tonight Tackles U.S. Primaries and Caucuses: The United States selection process for presidential nominees is convoluted — to say the least. Nevertheless, John Oliver reminds Americans that the "middle of the game" is the worst possible time to change the rules.

episodes.name: Debt Buyers
episodes.overview: John Oliver Takes On Debt Buyers: Companies that purchase debt on the cheap will aggressively collect on it. 'Last Week Tonight’ took a hands-on approach to addressing this issue.

episodes.name: Retirement Plans
episodes.overview: John Oliver Covers Ins and Outs of Retirement Plans: Saving for retirement means navigating a potential minefield of high fees and bad advice - Last Week Tonight is here to help.

episodes.name: Brexit
episodes.overview: John Oliver on “Brexiting” from the EU: There might be an innate British desire to diss Europe, but Last Week Tonight lays out exactly why it’s a mistake to leave the EU.

episodes.name: Doping
episodes.overview: John talks about the aftermath of the Brexit vote in the United Kingdom and doping in sports with the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio on the horizon.

episodes.name: Republican National Convention
episodes.overview: John talks about the disastrous Republican National Convention in Cleveland, where politicians were mostly talking about their feelings equating them to facts. Plus, Hillary Clinton's VP pick, the appointment of Boris Johnson as Britain's Foreign Secretary, the resignation of Roger Ailes from FOX and the unauthorized use of songs in political campaigns.

episodes.name: Democratic National Convention
episodes.overview: John covers the rocky Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. Plus, the military coup in Turkey and its aftermath, the voter ID laws targeting the minorities and how are tanning beds still a thing.

episodes.name: Journalism
episodes.overview: John Oliver has some bad news about the state of the industry that gives us our news. Plus, the coverage of the Opening Ceremony of Rio Olympics.

episodes.name: Auto Lending
episodes.overview: Auto lenders can steer vulnerable people into crushing debt. Keegan-Michael Key and Bob Balaban help John Oliver show exactly how.

episodes.name: Charter Schools
episodes.overview: Charter schools are privately run, publicly funded, and irregularly regulated. John Oliver explores why they aren’t at all like pizzerias.

episodes.name: Scandals
episodes.overview: Taking a walk down memory lane, 'Last Week Tonight' assesses Donald Trump's vs. Hillary Clinton's scandals.

episodes.name: Police Accountability
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the systems in place to investigate and hold police officers accountable for misconduct.

episodes.name: Guantánamo
episodes.overview: John Oliver examines the legal and moral issues surrounding the military prison at Guantánamo Bay.

episodes.name: Third Parties
episodes.overview: Third party candidates want to be serious contenders, so John Oliver considers them seriously as potential presidents.

episodes.name: Opioids
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the extent and root of the nation’s epidemic of opioid addiction.

episodes.name: School Segregation
episodes.overview: Public schools are increasingly divided by race and class. John Oliver discusses the troubling trend towards school resegregation.

episodes.name: Multilevel Marketing
episodes.overview: Multilevel marketing companies claim to be legitimate businesses, but some seems awfully pyramid shaped, and that's a problem.

episodes.name: President-Elect Trump
episodes.overview: The presidential race has been a hell of a ride. ‘Last Week Tonight’ closes out the election and Season 3 with a bang.

episodes.name: Trump vs. Truth
episodes.overview: Donald Trump spreads a lot of false information thanks to his daily consumption of morning cable news. If only we could sneak some facts into the president’s media diet.

episodes.name: Putin
episodes.overview: Vladimir Putin is known as a ruthless leader and master manipulator. John Oliver enlists a group of singing dancers to explain that to Donald Trump.

episodes.name: Obamacare
episodes.overview: Congressional Republicans could soon vote to repeal Obamacare. John Oliver explores why their replacement plans are similar to a thong.

episodes.name: Dalai Lama
episodes.overview: Tibetan Buddhists have suffered deep persecution by the Chinese government. John Oliver sits down with the Dalai Lama to discuss China, the conditions in Tibet, and horse milk.

episodes.name: American Health Care Act
episodes.overview: The Republican health care bill could leave many Americans without affordable coverage. Last Week Tonight's catheter cowboy returns to morning cable news to explain that to Donald Trump.

episodes.name: Federal Budget
episodes.overview: Donald Trump's federal budget plan proposes large funding cuts with largely negative consequences. John Oliver examines the troubling priorities of the new administration.

episodes.name: Marijuana
episodes.overview: Under federal law, even legal marijuana is illegal. John Oliver explains why conflicting drug laws pose serious problems.

episodes.name: Gerrymandering
episodes.overview: Lawmakers often reshape voting districts to shift the balance of political power. That's unfair to voters, even those of us with questionable judgment.

episodes.name: French Elections
episodes.overview: The presidential election in France could determine the political future of Europe. John Oliver visits an excessively French bistro to deliver an urgent message to voters.

episodes.name: Ivanka & Jared
episodes.overview: Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner hold an incredible amount of political power. That's troubling considering their incredibly small amount of political experience.

episodes.name: Net Neutrality II
episodes.overview: Equal access to online information is once again under serious threat. John Oliver encourages internet commenters to voice their displeasure to the FCC by visiting www.gofccyourself.com.

episodes.name: Dialysis
episodes.overview: For-profit dialysis companies often maximize their profits at the expense of their patients. John Oliver explores why a medical clinic is nothing like a Taco Bell.

episodes.name: Stupid Watergate
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the shocking magnitude and potential impact of the latest revelations surrounding the Russia investigation.

episodes.name: Paris Agreement
episodes.overview: Donald Trump plans to withdraw the United States from the Paris agreement on climate change. That's bad news for anyone who happens to live on this planet.

episodes.name: Brexit II
episodes.overview: In the wake of a divisive election, the UK will begin the process of leaving the European Union. John Oliver and an intergalactic space lord propose a plan.

episodes.name: Coal
episodes.overview: We’ve heard a lot of talk about coal miners in the last year, but what are the real issues surrounding coal? John Oliver and a giant squirrel look into it.

episodes.name: Vaccines
episodes.overview: The benefits of vaccines far outweigh the minuscule risks, but some parents still question their safety. John Oliver discusses why some people may still feel uncertainty about childhood vaccinations.

episodes.name: Sinclair Broadcast Group
episodes.overview: Sinclair Broadcast Group is the largest owner of local TV stations in the country. That's alarming considering that they often inject political views into local news.

episodes.name: Alex Jones
episodes.overview: Alex Jones is known for pushing conspiracy theories, but he also spends a lot of time promoting his own products. John Oliver and a “doctor” “from” M.I.T. test out his marketing strategy.

episodes.name: Border Patrol
episodes.overview: Donald Trump's plan to hire more Border Patrol agents could lead to more corruption and misconduct. If only their recruitment ads were designed to attract the most suitable applicants.

episodes.name: North Korea
episodes.overview: As nuclear tensions continue to escalate between the United States and North Korea, John Oliver enlists "Weird Al" Yankovic to perform some accordion-based diplomacy.

episodes.name: Nuclear Waste
episodes.overview: Nuclear waste poses a serious threat to public health if it's not stored in a safe place. John Oliver explains why the United States desperately needs to build a metaphorical toilet for all that waste.

episodes.name: Joe Arpaio
episodes.overview: Donald Trump issued his first presidential pardon to the last person who should get one. John Oliver discusses the troubling record of former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio.

episodes.name: Corporate Consolidation
episodes.overview: Big businesses are getting even bigger thanks to a rise in corporate mergers. John Oliver explains why that could make you want to physically destroy your cable box.

episodes.name: Forensic Science
episodes.overview: Forensic science used in criminal trials can be surprisingly unscientific. Maybe a new television procedural could help change the public perception.

episodes.name: Confederacy
episodes.overview: Confederate symbols are still celebrated despite the ugly history they symbolize. John Oliver suggests some representations of southern pride that involve less racism and more Stephen Colbert.

episodes.name: Equifax
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the massive impact of the cybersecurity breach at Equifax and their massively misguided attempts to mitigate the damage.

episodes.name: Floods
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why our federal system for financing flood recovery perpetuates a pattern of destruction and why you should never offer a tortilla chip to a seagull.

episodes.name: Economic Development
episodes.overview: State and local governments offer large financial incentives to attract employers to their part of the country. John Oliver explains what communities get, or often don't get, in return.

episodes.name: The Trump Presidency
episodes.overview: One year after the presidential election, John Oliver discusses what we've learned so far and enlists our catheter cowboy to teach Donald Trump what he hasn't.

episodes.name: Trump vs. The World
episodes.overview: America's reputation is being damaged by its own president. John Oliver, several dinosaurs, and the NYC Gay Men's Chorus remind the world that our country is...complicated.

episodes.name: Italian Election
episodes.overview: Italy is in the throes of a turbulent race to elect a new prime minister. John Oliver discusses the colorful contenders and introduces an equally ridiculous candidate.

episodes.name: NRA TV
episodes.overview: The NRA's streaming lifestyle network aims to boost gun sales, often by using an ominous tone that would make just about anything sound terrifying...including muffins.

episodes.name: Cryptocurrencies
episodes.overview: Digital currencies are generating a lot of excitement. John Oliver enlists Keegan-Michael Key to get potential investors equally excited about the concept of caution.

episodes.name: Mike Pence
episodes.overview: John Oliver can't help but say nice things about the Vice President's rabbit, Marlon Bundo. Last Week Tonight even wrote a children's book about him.

episodes.name: Immigration Courts
episodes.overview: America’s dysfunctional immigration court system forces many children to appear in court alone. That’s as ridiculous in real life as it would be on a courtroom television show.

episodes.name: Crisis Pregnancy Centers
episodes.overview: Crisis pregnancy centers deceptively steer woman away from abortion. They can be started way too easily by religious groups like, for instance, a late night talk show’s megachurch.

episodes.name: Corporate Taxes
episodes.overview: Many of America’s largest corporations shift a surprising portion of their profits overseas to avoid paying taxes. Even more surprisingly, that’s a legal thing to do.

episodes.name: Iran Deal
episodes.overview: Donald Trump could soon dismantle the agreement designed to curb the Iranian nuclear program. Our catheter cowboy will do his best to keep that from happening.

episodes.name: Rudy Giuliani
episodes.overview: Rudy Giuliani is new to Trump’s legal team, but not to public controversy. Last Week Tonight examines his turbulent record in the wake of his recent political upsets.

episodes.name: Venezuela
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the devastating economic crisis in Venezuela and enlists the help of a large bird who bears a striking resemblance to Wilmer Valderrama.

episodes.name: Drug Rehabilitation Clinics
episodes.overview: Other segments: Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, proposed 2018 North Korea-United States summit

episodes.name: Guardianship
episodes.overview: It’s alarmingly easy for a total stranger to gain total control over the life of a senior citizen. We enlisted a group of celebrities to offer a warning about predatory behavior...in a legal guardian or a hippo.

episodes.name: Stupid Watergate II
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how the president and his allies are going full O. J. in order to undermine the investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election.

episodes.name: Xi Jinping
episodes.overview: Chinese president Xi Jinping is amassing an alarming amount of political power. If only his propaganda videos made the idea of unrestricted authority seem as troubling as the concept of singing children.

episodes.name: Mexican Elections
episodes.overview: Mexico is on the verge of a major election. John Oliver discusses some things we should know about the races and one thing we should not know about Santa Claus.

episodes.name: Gene Editing
episodes.overview: Scientists are developing new ways to alter the genetic code of living organisms. John Oliver explores the risks, rewards, and wolf-related hazards of gene editing.

episodes.name: Workplace Sexual Harassment
episodes.overview: With a national dialogue underway about sexual harassment in the workplace, John Oliver sits down with Anita Hill to discuss the recent response to a not-so-recent problem.

episodes.name: Prosecutors
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how prosecutors use, or in some cases misuse, their power within our criminal justice system and why it’s important to know whether or not your district attorney is a dog.

episodes.name: Astroturfing
episodes.overview: Organizations can hire fake advocates who create the illusion of real support for their message. It’s a shady practice called astroturfing that can warp the public perception of anything...even astroturfing.

episodes.name: Trade
episodes.overview: Donald Trump is waging a trade war that hurts a lot of American workers. Maybe he would understand that if our heavy-handed documentaries about the global trading system were more informative.

episodes.name: Felony Disenfranchisement
episodes.overview: Many people with felony convictions are unfairly prohibited from voting, and the worst state for this — surprise — is Florida.

episodes.name: Facebook
episodes.overview: Facebook’s global expansion has been linked to political turmoil overseas, so maybe their ads should focus less on how they “connect the world” and more on why connecting people isn’t always the best idea.

episodes.name: Brett Kavanaugh
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the ongoing controversy surrounding Brett Kavanaugh, the sexual assault allegations against him, his Supreme Court nomination, and what that could all mean for the highest (mostly-dog) court in the land.

episodes.name: Brazilian Elections
episodes.overview: Brazil is about to elect a new president during a turbulent period of political corruption and economic uncertainty. John Oliver urges the people of Brazil not to figuratively fingerbang their democracy.

episodes.name: Saudi Arabia
episodes.overview: Following the alarming disappearance of a Saudi journalist and political dissident, John Oliver examines America's uncomfortably comfortable relationship with Saudi Arabia.

episodes.name: State Attorneys General
episodes.overview: State AGs have become major partisan players in national politics, so the races to elect them are worth your attention.

episodes.name: Family Separation
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the disturbing policy that separated migrant families detained at our southern border, and the disturbingly real chance that it could happen again.

episodes.name: Drain the Swamp
episodes.overview: Donald Trump promised to “drain the swamp.” But considering the culture of corruption inside of his administration, Washington is looking awfully...swampy.

episodes.name: Authoritarianism
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the growing number of authoritarian leaders around the world, their common characteristics, and whether or not one of them is currently our president.

episodes.name: Brexit III
episodes.overview: The UK could officially leave the European Union next month, which would be a huge change with hugely damaging consequences.

episodes.name: Psychics
episodes.overview: Psychics may seem harmless and fun on TV, but they can make a lot of money by exploiting vulnerable people.

episodes.name: Automation
episodes.overview: Automation often seems like a scary new problem, but it’s neither entirely scary nor entirely new.

episodes.name: Robocalls
episodes.overview: Robocalls are a growing problem. If only we could make the FCC care a little bit more about fixing it.

episodes.name: Public Shaming
episodes.overview: John Oliver talks about the power of public shaming, good and bad.

episodes.name: WWE
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses how the WWE takes care of its wrestlers — and how it doesn’t.

episodes.name: Mobile Homes
episodes.overview: Mobile homes may seem like an affordable housing option, but large investment companies are making them less and less so.

episodes.name: Opioids II
episodes.overview: Following some recent revelations about the role of large companies in America’s ongoing opioid epidemic, John Oliver takes another look at the crisis.

episodes.name: Mueller Report
episodes.overview: Following the release of the Mueller Report, John Oliver discusses what we’ve learned.

episodes.name: Lethal Injections
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the lethal injection process, which is definitely not as pleasant as talking about a squeaking frog.

episodes.name: Green New Deal
episodes.overview: With the Green New Deal sparking a national conversation about all the ways to combat climate change, John Oliver looks at a few potential solutions.

episodes.name: Death Investigations
episodes.overview: America’s system for conducting death investigations is a mess. John Oliver explains why we should all be a little more concerned about fixing it.

episodes.name: Medical Devices
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the medical device industry, which is a huge business with a hugely troubling lack of regulation.

episodes.name: Equal Rights Amendment
episodes.overview: There’s still nothing in our constitution that explicitly prohibits sex discrimination. John Oliver talks about how to fix that.

episodes.name: Impeachment
episodes.overview: With a national conversation underway about the possibility of impeachment, John Oliver discusses whether the benefits outweigh the potential risks.

episodes.name: Everest
episodes.overview: Climbing Mount Everest has become dangerously popular. John Oliver explains why.

episodes.name: Warehouses
episodes.overview: It’s easy to buy things online, and even easier not to think about how they get to you. John Oliver discusses what happens when you click “buy now.”

episodes.name: Boris Johnson
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how Britain’s new prime minister, Boris Johnson, has succeeded – not despite his bumbling persona, but often because of it.

episodes.name: Prison Labor
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how prisoners make and spend money, and how companies can profit at the expense of their families.

episodes.name: Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov
episodes.overview: John Oliver takes a look at the president of Turkmenistan, a dangerous autocrat with some notably strange obsessions.

episodes.name: Bias in Medicine
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the roles that gender and racial bias can play in medical treatment.

episodes.name: Filibuster
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why filibusters exist, why they shouldn't, and why it's stupid to drink coffee like a cat.

episodes.name: Legal Immigration
episodes.overview: Legal immigration is a term which was repeated throughout the Trump presidency. But John Oliver explains its absurdity as well as why people resort to illegal means to enter the country. He breaks down all the four ways a person can enter USA legally: Family, Employment, Good Luck (Visa Lottery), Bad Luck (Refugee).

episodes.name: Compounding Pharmacies
episodes.overview: Compounding pharmacies create medication tailored to the specific needs of individual patients. John Oliver explains why this small corner of the drug market can cause big problems.

episodes.name: One Child Policy
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses China’s one-child policy, and all its consequences, intended and not.

episodes.name: Weather
episodes.overview: John talks about Weather forecasting, Barry Lee Myers and the National Weather Service

episodes.name: Trump & Syria
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the alarming decision to pull U.S. troops away from the border between Turkey and Syria.

episodes.name: Voting Machines
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses how voting machines work, how they don’t, and how we can fix them.

episodes.name: SLAPP Suits
episodes.overview: After winning a legal battle involving a coal executive and a giant squirrel, John Oliver explains how SLAPP suits are designed to stifle public dissent.

episodes.name: The Census
episodes.overview: Main story: 2020 United States Census; plus, the impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump and Chiitan.

episodes.name: Medicare for All
episodes.overview: Main story: The pros and cons of Medicare for All; plus, Bill Barr does Trump's personal bidding; and Flyers mascot Gritty is exonerated!

episodes.name: Modi
episodes.overview: Main story: John Oliver talks about India's controversial Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, and his government's Hindu nationalism; plus, a look at Mike Bloomberg's presidential campaign.

episodes.name: Coronavirus
episodes.overview: John covers the Covid-19 pandemic, how each country, including the US, is handling it, and why the Phillie Phanatic is in a copyright row. Also, Tom Steyer quits the Democratic presidential race, and Chris Matthews messes up his sign offs.

episodes.name: Sheriffs
episodes.overview: Main story: A look at how much power and how little accountability local sheriffs have; plus, Trump's coronavirus incompetence; India's self-censorship of 'Last Week Tonight.'

episodes.name: Coronavirus II
episodes.overview: Main story: 2019–20 coronavirus outbreak, governmental response in the US, and the prevention of COVID-19. This episode was filmed at an unspecified location with no live audience as the studio and the show's offices were shut down after employees tested positive for COVID-19. John Oliver stated the show will go on hiatus for an unspecified amount of time but will definitely return.

episodes.name: Coronavirus III
episodes.overview: In the first show from his makeshift home studio, John covers the horrible way COVID-19 pandemic is going and how Trump is mishandling it, how TV hosts are practicing social distancing, and how profoundly gleeful 90s erotic rat art can be.

episodes.name: One America News Network
episodes.overview: John criticizes the Republican governors' response to the pandemic, showcases how everyone filming from home gets asked if they're wearing pants, and warns of the new ultra right wing, extremely pro-Trump network called OAN(N).

episodes.name: Essential Workers
episodes.overview: John explains how the Trump administration failed to protect the unemployed, small businesses and essential workers during the pandemic, the peeps make their unholy return, and 90s rat erotica makes John's day once again.

episodes.name: Coronavirus Misinformation
episodes.overview: John analyzes the right wing media's protests, conspiracy theories and misinformation spreading about the pandemic, spotlights Inside Edition's latest 'coming up' segments, and becomes a fan of the home edition of The Wendy Williams Show.

episodes.name: COVID-19 Testing
episodes.overview: John points out the failure of The FDA and federal government when experts encourage widespread coronavirus testing for several months. The number of tests being done everyday far behind the lowest recommended number. John talks about the different types of tests: diagnostic and antibody tests, and how the tests work.

episodes.name: United States Postal Service
episodes.overview: John discusses the United States Postal Service which is in dire need of economic assistance from the government. He examines some of the essential services of the USPS and why it is facing such financial trouble due to a 2006 law requiring it to pre-pay health care benefits on a fifty year schedule while at the same time putting price caps on services and products.

episodes.name: Coronavirus Impact on Sports
episodes.overview: John discusses the sudden disappearance of sports due to coronavirus, how their absence is impacting people emotionally and financially, and the complications of bringing them back anytime soon.

episodes.name: Postal Voting
episodes.overview: John explains the importance of voting by mail. Also, mass protests against police brutality erupt in Minneapolis, TV hosts inquire about the odd objects behind their stay-at-home guests, and John schools UFC president Dana White.

episodes.name: Police
episodes.overview: This episode tackles the hard truth about the history of Police in the United States and the many problems that are faced in fixing those problems.

episodes.name: Facial Recognition
episodes.overview: Facial recognition is no longer an issue of a thriller movie. It has become a part of our life. John Oliver talks about various aspects and global practice of facial recognition technology. He explains how dangerous it could be by addressing the questionable activities of facial recognition company Clearview AI.

episodes.name: Prisons & Jails
episodes.overview: In the latest episode on coronavirus John talks about US prisons and jails. These confined spaces have frightening number of COVID-19 infections. And there has been insufficient initiatives to address the matter. Consequently, in some cases inmates are taking matters in their own hand to raise concern about situation behind bars.

episodes.name: Coronavirus IX: Evictions
episodes.overview: Like coronavirus and unemployment issues evictions is something that USA could prepared for. While people are choosing between rent and food due to the pandemic, John Oliver presented the flaws of current system and flawed solution. He urges federal government to come with a proper solution for the affected soon. Also, some people refuse to wear masks, and Papa John embraces TikTok.

episodes.name: Conspiracy Theories
episodes.overview: Conspiracy theories are the hotcakes of the internet. John talks about why people like these conspiracy theories and why in the age of internet it spreads so quickly. He also explains the detrimental effect can have on people's life. Finally celebrities urges people to be more vigilant and inquisitive about these theories as majority of these theories are baseless and created to create unrest among people.

episodes.name: Uighurs
episodes.overview: The Uighur people are facing human rights abuses in China; plus, Trump’s authoritarian show of force in Portland; Martha Stewart loosens up.

episodes.name: U.S. History
episodes.overview: A look at how the history of race is taught in schools; plus, Trump pushes bad medicine; Louie Gohmert tests positive; and Steve Guttenberg has a 'Cameo.'

episodes.name: Juries
episodes.overview: John Oliver takes a look at why people of color are routinely excluded from becoming jurors, who their absence impacts, and what we can do to create a fairer system.

episodes.name: Border Wall
episodes.overview: Nearing the 2020 election, John Oliver checks in on one of the key promises of President Trump’s 2016 campaign: the border wall. Plus, The “Unconventional Convention”; the return of Pumpkin Spice.

episodes.name: RNC 2020 & Kenosha
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses a week that saw the Republican National Convention, a horrific series of shootings in Kenosha, Wisconsin, and a strike in professional sports -- three stories that are really one story, about race in America.

episodes.name: Supreme Court
episodes.overview: In the wake of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death, John Oliver discusses the future of the Supreme Court, why the government doesn’t always represent the political leanings of the electorate, and how those issues will impact the next generation of Americans.

episodes.name: Election 2020
episodes.overview: Weeks out from the 2020 presidential election, John Oliver takes a look at various efforts to destabilize the vote, how to ensure your ballot is properly counted, and why we may need to prepare not just for an election night, but for an election month.

episodes.name: The World Health Organization
episodes.overview: John Oliver talks about the functions of World Health Organization and why it is a vital part of the upcoming US election. John points out the contribution WHO made over the years, explains the reason why USA pays more than other countries and describes the mistakes of this highly impactful organization.

episodes.name: Asylum
episodes.overview: John Oliver talks about the situation of asylum seekers in USA under Trump administration. He points out the three major changes in policy (migrant protection protocols, safe third country agreements and Title 42) which are deciding the future of asylum seekers.

episodes.name: Trump & the Coronavirus and William Barr
episodes.overview: John Oliver takes a look at how the Trump administration has handled the coronavirus outbreak in the US, from lack of preparation, to mangled coordination, to harmful communication. John also discusses William Barr’s attitude toward authority and executive power, how that attitude has influenced Donald Trump’s presidency, and what it could mean if Trump wins a second term.

episodes.name: Election Results 2020
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the long week of US presidential election results, including Donald Trump’s various attempts to make the election appear illegitimate, and a historic win for Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.

episodes.name: Trump & Election Results
episodes.overview: A week after Joe Biden’s win in the US presidential election, John Oliver discusses Donald Trump’s various attempts to overturn the results, why his claims don’t hold water, and the consequences of indulging him.

episodes.name: Episode 210: The Next Pandemic
episodes.overview: Main story: What could cause the next pandemic, what we can do to avoid it, and why you shouldn’t kiss pigs; plus, Impeachment Part 2.

episodes.name: Episode 211: Meatpacking
episodes.overview: Main story: Working conditions in the meatpacking industry; plus, the Texas power crisis in the wake of severe winter weather.

episodes.name: Episode 212: Raids
episodes.overview: Main story: How few guardrails there are on the use of police raids; plus, New York governor Andrew Cuomo faces multiple scandals.

episodes.name: Episode 213: Unemployment
episodes.overview: Main story: The many obstacles that impede access to unemployment benefits; plus, Fox News freaks out over Dr. Seuss.

episodes.name: Episode 214: Tucker Carlson
episodes.overview: Main story: Where Tucker Carlson came from and why he's admired by white nationalists; plus, reaction to the Biden COVID-19 relief bill.

episodes.name: Episode 215: Plastics
episodes.overview: Main story: How plastics are harming the planet, and why recycling isn’t the solution you think it is; plus, the Atlanta mass shootings and hate crimes against Asian-Americans.

episodes.name: Episode 216: The National Debt
episodes.overview: Main story: How national debt works and why it might be more helpful than you'd think; plus, Giuliani freaks over Lil Nas X; Amazon's anti-union tactics; Peeps and Pepsi form an unholy alliance.

episodes.name: Episode 217: Long-Term Care
episodes.overview: Main story: Why nursing homes and assisted living facilities need fixing; plus, the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program; Matt Gaetz and Venmo; R.I.P. Yahoo! Answers.

episodes.name: Episode 218: Bankruptcy
episodes.overview: John Oliver details why people file for bankruptcy, how needlessly difficult the process can be, and the ways we can better serve people struggling with debt.

episodes.name: Episode 219: Vaccine
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why some people don't want to get the Covid-19 vaccine and how they might be reassured.

episodes.name: Episode 220: Hair
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the importance of black hair, the ways it can be a target of discrimination, and some ideas to address that.

episodes.name: Episode 221: Stand Your Ground
episodes.overview: Main Story: John Oliver takes a look at why “stand your ground” laws were created, who they protect, and, crucially, who they don’t. Plus, a look at the past week’s events in Israel.

episodes.name: Episode 222: Sponcon
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why the integrity of local news is so important, how sponsored content could damage that integrity, and why the Venus Veil is so much more than a blanket. (It's not.)

episodes.name: Episode 223: Asian Americans
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the large and diverse group of people who fall under the term "Asian American", the history of the model minority stereotype, and why our conversations on the subject need to be better-informed.

episodes.name: Episode 224: Prison Heat
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how the failure to air-condition prisons can cause both physical and mental health issues for incarcerated people, and why the solution is simpler than you might think. Plus, some truly unique local car dealership ads.

episodes.name: Episode 225: PACE
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how PACE, a program meant to pay for environmentally-friendly home renovations, is fundamentally flawed and can put people at risk of losing their homes. Plus, why hosting summer Olympics in Tokyo this year is a bad idea and why dog shows are weird.

episodes.name: Episode 226: Health Care Sharing Ministries
episodes.overview: Health Care Sharing Ministries, or HCSMs, advertise themselves as a more affordable, faith-based alternative to health insurance. But John Oliver explains some of the massive limitations these plans can have.

episodes.name: Episode 227: Housing Discrimination
episodes.overview: John Oliver breaks down the long history of housing discrimination in the U.S., the damage it's done, and, crucially, what we can do about it.

episodes.name: Episode 228: Emergency Medical Services
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how emergency medical services function in the U.S., why they can be so expensive, and what we can do to fix things.

episodes.name: Episode 229: Opioids III – The Sacklers
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how the Sackler family has been handling lawsuits related to the opioid crisis, how hard they've been fighting to defend their name, and why you should judge the situation for yourself.

episodes.name: Episode 230: Ransomware
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses ransomware attacks, why they’re on the rise, and what can be done about them.

episodes.name: Episode 231: Afghanistan
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the end of America's war with Afghanistan and the humanitarian crisis being left behind.

episodes.name: Episode 232:  Lukashenko
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the longtime leader of Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko, and the many reasons his country's citizens have not to like him.

episodes.name: Episode 233: Voting Rights
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the current attacks on voting rights, who's behind them, and what we can do about it. Plus, John enters several paintings in the annual Duck Stamp contest.

episodes.name: Episode 234: PFAS
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses PFAS - a class of chemicals linked to an array of health issues - and why their widespread use isn't as magical as it may seem.

episodes.name: Episode 235
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses how misinformation spreads among immigrant diaspora communities, how little some platforms have done to stop it, and, most importantly, how to have a very good morning.

episodes.name: Episode 236
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses Taiwan's history of being governed by other countries, its fraught present-day relationship with China, and what its citizens would want their future to look like.

episodes.name: Episode 237
episodes.overview: With homelessness increasing nationwide, John Oliver takes a look at the way we discuss the unhoused, what policy failures are making the problem worse, and how we can help.

episodes.name: Episode 238
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the current state of the nation's power grid, why it needs fixing, and, of course, how fun the balloons are.

episodes.name: Episode 239
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the mechanics of union busting, why the companies who do it face so few consequences, and what it really means when your manager wants to talk to you about "your attendance."

episodes.name: February 20, 2022: Critical Race Theory
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains what critical race theory is, what it isn't, and why we can expect to hear more about it in the coming months. Plus, the Canadian trucker protests.

episodes.name: February 27, 2022: Sex Work
episodes.overview: As long as sex work has existed, so have efforts to end it. John Oliver explains why criminalizing the trade hasn’t helped the most vulnerable people involved, and why we should start listening to those at the center of the conversation: sex workers. Plus, Russian invasion into Ukraine, that has placed the whole world at the brink of WW3.

episodes.name: March 6, 2022: Wrongful Convictions
episodes.overview: John Oliver talks about the current practices of overturning wrongful convictions and how it is quite unsupportive of even apparently innocent people. He advocates for urgent reforms in the flawed system which is clearly not working in favor of the innocents. Plus, the heroic resistance of Ukrainians against the invasion of Russia.

episodes.name: March 13, 2022: Tickets
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains why concert tickets are so expensive, who’s making money off of them, and which One Direction is his favorite. Plus, the introduction of some appalling anti-LGBT laws in several states.

episodes.name: March 27, 2022: Harm Reduction
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses why overdoses in the U.S. have been on the rise and what we should, and shouldn't, be doing to prevent them. Plus, a rather odd yearly tradition in Nenana, Alaska.

episodes.name: April 3, 2022: Trucks
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains how truck drivers get paid, how they often don’t, and how companies exploit them to increase profits. Plus, Republican congressman Madison Cawthorn's tales of GOP orgies and drug use has him in trouble with his own party.

episodes.name: April 10, 2022: Data Brokers
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses how much data brokers know about us, what they’re doing with our personal information, and one unusual way to change privacy laws. Plus, Russian State TV lies about the Ukraine war; DirecTV drops OAN; John says goodbye to AT&T.

episodes.name: April 17, 2022: Police Interrogations
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the tactics that can make police interrogations so damaging, particularly to the innocent. Plus, a look at Dr. Oz's campaign for U.S. Senate.

episodes.name: May 1, 2022: Environmental Racism
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses environmental racism, how both government and industry are failing people of color and how zoning is manipulating the same people to live in adverse conditions. Plus, pandas doing some weird things and 'gas math' by Shaquille O'Neal.

episodes.name: May 8, 2022: Abortion Ruling/Philippines Election
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the current presidential election in The Philippines and why Bongbong Marcos is - albeit in a very limited and unflattering way - sort of like Ant-Man. Plus, the leaked anti-abortion draft opinion that looks set to overturn Roe v. Wade, how we got to this point, and where we may be headed.

episodes.name: May 15, 2022: Utilities
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the incredible amount of power we give electric utility companies, how weakly regulated they are, and why they get such bad Yelp reviews. Plus, a look at Alabama's extreme anti-trans law and some ridiculous participants of the Eurovision Song Contest 2022.

episodes.name: May 22, 2022: Subway
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses one of the largest franchises in the U.S., how their business model doesn’t always serve franchisees, and what it all has to do with Korean dramas.

episodes.name: June 5, 2022: School Police
episodes.overview: In the wake of the mass shooting in Uvalde, John Oliver discusses the push for more police in schools and whether they are the answer to school safety issues, or a new problem altogether. Plus, John makes an offer for a banana sculpture in Australia.

episodes.name: June 12, 2022: Tech Monopolies
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses tech monopolies such as Apple, Google, Amazon, and Facebook, and how to address the hidden harm they can do. Plus, a look at the hotly contested U.S. Senate race in Arizona, which includes Trump-endorsed candidate Blake Masters.

episodes.name: June 19, 2022: Rent
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses why rent has become increasingly unaffordable, what we can do to combat a system that is stacked against tenants, and, of course, Dakota Johnson’s complex relationship to limes. Plus, a look at GOP primary winners claiming the 2020 election was stolen.

episodes.name: June 26, 2022: Water
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the water shortage in the American west; plus, the Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

episodes.name: July 24, 2022: Inflation
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the causes of inflation and what we've done about it; plus, updates on the beach dolls and the banana sculpture.

episodes.name: July 31, 2022: Mental Health Care
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the cracks in our broken mental health care system; plus, a look at who's running to become the UK's prime minister.

episodes.name: August 7, 2022: Monkeypox
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the recent monkeypox outbreak in the U.S., how the authorities have fumbled the response to it, and some aspirations for this coming autumn. Plus, Walter from Butler, Indiana, likes to share stuff, perhaps a little too much.

episodes.name: August 14, 2022: Afghanistan
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses what’s happened since the U.S. withdrew from Afghanistan, how their ongoing crisis has even more to do with our decisions than you might think, and how to properly modify the verb “feel”. Plus, some true masterpieces of an AI-generated art.

episodes.name: August 21, 2022: Carbon Offsets
episodes.overview: John Oliver explains what carbon offsets are, what they claim to do, how they might be making climate change even worse, and, of course, how Oscar Isaac is getting hotter.

episodes.name: September 11, 2022: Law & Order
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the wildly popular television franchise, what it’s been teaching us about law enforcement, and how it differs from the reality. Plus, some important developments in British politics.

episodes.name: September 25, 2022: Bolsonaro
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses Jair Bolsonaro, how he's run Brazil as president and how far he might go to maintain power after the upcoming election. Plus, the absurd stunt by Florida's Governor Ron DeSantis involving Martha's Vineyard and why people in Puerto Rico are getting fed up by the electric company Luma.

episodes.name: October 2, 2022: Museums
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses some of the world's most prestigious museums, why they contain so many stolen goods, the market that continues to illegally trade antiquities, and a pretty solid blueprint for revenge. Plus, the disappearance of the British PM Liz Truss.

episodes.name: October 9, 2022: Crime Reporting
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the outlets that cover crime, the incentives that drive them, the flawed sources they rely upon, and an alternative name for Miss Piggy. Plus, why teenage girls in Iran are leading massive protests against the current regime.

episodes.name: October 16, 2022: Transgender Rights II
episodes.overview: John Oliver discusses the latest round of attacks on transgender rights, what’s at stake, and how kids are schooling the ignorant adults on this topic. Plus, why the Crimean Bridge is having a bad time these days.

episodes.name: October 30, 2022: Bail Reform
episodes.overview: With the U.S. midterm elections approaching, John Oliver discusses the issue at the core of many republican attack ads: bail reform. Plus, the turmoil in British politics after the resignation of PM Liz Truss.

episodes.name: November 6, 2022: Election Subversion
